diagnoses.description: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: SLE can present with acute pericarditis, pericardial effusion, psychosis (neuropsychiatric lupus), proteinuria (indicating lupus nephritis), and leukopenia due to its systemic involvement and autoimmune nature.

diagnoses.description: Mixed connective tissue disease
diagnoses.rationale: This disorder shares features of multiple autoimmune diseases including SLE, and can present with pericarditis, proteinuria, leukopenia, and neuropsychiatric symptoms.

diagnoses.description: Rheumatoid arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: While primarily known for joint issues, severe cases can involve pericarditis, proteinuria due to renal involvement, and hematological abnormalities including leukopenia.

diagnoses.description: Scleroderma
diagnoses.rationale: Scleroderma can cause pericardial effusion and kidney damage leading to proteinuria. The immune dysregulation might also result in leukopenia.

diagnoses.description: Viral myocarditis
diagnoses.rationale: Certain viral infections can lead to myocarditis with pericardial effusion and acute pericarditis. They can also cause systemic symptoms including leukopenia and, less commonly, proteinuria.

diagnoses.description: Drug-induced lupus erythematosus
diagnoses.rationale: Certain medications can induce a lupus-like syndrome presenting with pericarditis, leukopenia, and sometimes proteinuria.

diagnoses.description: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.rationale: Extrapulmonary TB can involve the pericardium, causing pericardial effusion and acute pericarditis. It can also lead to proteinuria if the kidneys are involved and leukopenia due to bone marrow involvement or chronic disease state.

diagnoses.description: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.rationale: HIV infection can present with a range of symptoms including leukopenia due to the virus's destruction of white cells, proteinuria as a part of HIV-associated nephropathy, and pericardial effusion in advanced disease.

diagnoses.description: Lymphoma
diagnoses.rationale: Some lymphomas may present with pericardial effusion, leukopenia due to bone marrow infiltration, acute pericarditis, proteinuria if the kidneys are involved, and nonspecific symptoms including psychosis in advanced cases.

diagnoses.description: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.rationale: Sarcoidosis is a granulomatous disease that can cause pericardial effusion, leukopenia, and acute pericarditis. Kidney involvement and neuropsychiatric manifestations are less common but possible.

diagnoses.name: Viral Infection
diagnoses.reasoning: Common viral infections can cause symptoms such as lymphadenopathy (swollen lymph nodes), coryza (cold-like symptoms), and skin manifestations like warts.

diagnoses.name: Human Papillomavirus (HPV) Infection
diagnoses.reasoning: HPV can cause warts and has been associated with lymphadenopathy due to the body's immune response.

diagnoses.name: Upper Respiratory Tract Infection
diagnoses.reasoning: Such infections often lead to coryza and can also cause lymphadenopathy due to the immune response.

diagnoses.name: Allergic Reactions
diagnoses.reasoning: Allergies can cause symptoms like angioedema (swelling under the skin), coryza, and sometimes lymphadenopathy if the reaction is severe.

diagnoses.name: Mononucleosis
diagnoses.reasoning: Caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, mononucleosis can lead to symptoms including lymphadenopathy, and in some cases, skin rashes that could be confused with warts.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.reasoning: HIV can cause lymphadenopathy, and as the immune system weakens, opportunistic infections may cause symptoms like warts and other skin problems.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.reasoning: A type of cancer that affects the lymphatic system, causing lymphadenopathy, and can also lead to a variety of systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Diseases
diagnoses.reasoning: Conditions like lupus can cause widespread immune responses leading to lymphadenopathy, angioedema, and other systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Syphilis
diagnoses.reasoning: A bacterial infection that can present with lymphadenopathy, and in its secondary stage can present with various skin manifestations, potentially resembling warts.

diagnoses.name: Medication Side Effects
diagnoses.reasoning: Certain medications can cause side effects including lymphadenopathy, angioedema, and changes in the skin that may mimic warts.

diagnoses.name: Viral Upper Respiratory Infection
diagnoses.details: Common cold or flu can affect the nose, throat, and ears, leading to symptoms like dysosmia, oral pain, irritated eyes, and otitis media. Lymphadenopathy can occur as the immune system fights the infection.

diagnoses.name: Bacterial Sinusitis
diagnoses.details: Infection of the sinuses can spread to surrounding regions, including the ears and lymph nodes, causing a wide range of symptoms such as dysosmia due to nasal congestion, lymphadenopathy, oral pain, and otitis media.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.details: An autoimmune disease that attacks the glands that produce tears and saliva, leading to dry eyes (irritated eyes), dry mouth (oral pain), and potential complications like lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Mononucleosis
diagnoses.details: Caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, it can lead to severe lymphadenopathy, oral pain due to throat infection, and general discomfort including symptoms like irritated eyes.

diagnoses.name: Stevens-Johnson Syndrome
diagnoses.details: A rare, serious disorder of the skin and mucous membranes, often reacting to a medication or infection. It can cause symptoms like oral pain, dysosmia, and irritated eyes.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.details: Early stages of HIV or advanced stages leading to AIDS can manifest as lymphadenopathy, oral pain due to opportunistic infections, and other systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.details: This inflammatory disease can affect any part of the body but primarily the lungs and lymphatic system, leading to lymphadenopathy; eyes and skin can also be affected, causing symptoms like irritated eyes.

diagnoses.name: Measles
diagnoses.details: A highly contagious viral disease that can cause symptoms such as Koplik's spots inside the mouth (oral pain), conjunctivitis (irritated eyes), and lymphadenopathy due to the immune response.

diagnoses.name: Allergic Rhinitis
diagnoses.details: An allergic response causing symptoms like dysosmia due to nasal congestion, possibly leading to secondary infections like otitis media and accompanying symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Scarlet Fever
diagnoses.details: A bacterial illness that can occur in some people who have strep throat. It's marked by a bright red rash, fever, and sore throat, potentially leading to symptoms like oral pain and lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia Vera
diagnoses.description: A type of blood cancer that causes the bone marrow to make too many red blood cells. These excess cells thicken the blood, slowing its flow, which may cause complications such as blood clots. This condition may contribute to symptoms such as polycythemia and presyncope.

diagnoses.name: Esophageal cancer
diagnoses.description: Cancer that occurs in the esophagus, the long, hollow tube that runs from your throat to your stomach. Esophageal cancer can cause symptoms such as dysphagia and presyncope due to obstruction or pressure effects.

diagnoses.name: Chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML)
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that starts in the blood-forming cells of the bone marrow and invades the blood. It can lead to increased red blood cell count (polycythemia) and muscle pain, among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Primary myelofibrosis
diagnoses.description: A rare bone marrow cancer that disrupts the body's normal production of blood cells, leading to polycythemia, dysphagia (due to spleen enlargement), and muscle pain.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your thyroid gland doesn't produce enough important hormones. It can contribute to muscle pain, and in rare situations, it may lead to an elevated red blood cell count and dysphagia if significant swelling and obstruction occur.

diagnoses.name: Secondary polycythemia
diagnoses.description: Occurs when excess red blood cells are produced as a response to an underlying condition, such as chronic hypoxia or tumors producing erythropoietin. This can associate with symptoms like presyncope but less commonly with dysphagia unless there are other complications.

diagnoses.name: Multiple myeloma
diagnoses.description: A cancer that forms in a type of white blood cell called a plasma cell. Plasma cells help you fight infections by making antibodies that recognize and attack germs. Multiple myeloma causes cancer cells to accumulate in the bone marrow, where they crowd out healthy blood cells. While not directly causing polycythemia, symptoms like muscle pain are common.

diagnoses.name: Iron deficiency anemia
diagnoses.description: Anemia caused by a lack of iron in the body. Though typically associated with low red blood cell counts, complicated cases can present with a high red blood cell count due to various physiological compensatory mechanisms. Symptoms can include dysphagia due to the formation of esophageal webs.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid cancer
diagnoses.description: Cancer that forms in the thyroid gland (located at the base of your throat). Though not directly causing polycythemia, it can lead to symptoms like dysphagia if the growing tumor compresses the esophagus.

diagnoses.name: Esophageal stricture
diagnoses.description: A narrowing of the esophagus that can cause dysphagia. While it doesn't directly cause polycythemia or muscle pain, it can be a secondary condition that complicates the underlying cause of these symptoms, such as chronic gastrointestinal bleeding contributing to an elevated red blood cell count through compensatory mechanisms.

diagnoses: Hypertension associated with Chronic Kidney Disease
Autoimmune Disorders (Potential cause for migratory patchy macular erythema)
Erythema Multiforme (A form of erythema that could match the description)
Acute Infectious Mononucleosis (Can present with Monocytosis and erythema)
Kawasaki Disease (Coronary artery involvement could mimic Kounis syndrome)
Kounis Syndrome (Given as a symptom but also a diagnosis due to its specificity)
Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (Can lead to Kounis syndrome, migratory erythema, and increased infection susceptibility)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome

diagnoses.name: Chronic Stress
diagnoses.description: Long-term stress can lead to a variety of symptoms, including laryngitis (from stress-induced acid reflux or shouting), decreased libido, dyspepsia, lymphadenitis (from a weakened immune system), and difficulties concentrating, which can mimic attention deficit.

diagnoses.name: Depression
diagnoses.description: Depression can manifest physically and psychologically, leading to decreased libido, dyspepsia, attention deficit, and potentially indirectly causing laryngitis (through behaviors like excessive alcohol use) and lymphadenitis (from reduced immunity).

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: This complex disorder is characterized by profound fatigue, dyspepsia, attention difficulties, and potentially could be associated with laryngitis and lymphadenitis as part of its wide range of symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Hyperthyroidism
diagnoses.description: Hyperthyroidism's influence on metabolism could lead to dyspepsia and decreased libido. While less directly, it may contribute to laryngitis (from hormonal changes affecting the voice), lymphadenitis (from an overactive immune response), and attention deficit.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: HIV/AIDS can cause a wide range of symptoms due to its impact on the immune system, including lymphadenitis, dyspepsia, and potentially affecting cognitive functions to produce symptoms like attention deficit, besides impacting general health and potentially leading to conditions like laryngitis.

diagnoses.name: Generalized Anxiety Disorder
diagnoses.description: Anxiety can manifest with a variety of physical and psychological symptoms, including dyspepsia, decreased libido, attention deficit, and potentially mediating conditions like laryngitis and lymphadenitis through chronic stress.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: Symptoms of iron deficiency anemia can include attention deficit and decreased libido. While less directly, it could potentially contribute to dyspepsia, and any resulting weakened immune system might indirectly lead to conditions like lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: Diabetes can cause various symptoms including dyspepsia, and its effects on the nervous and immune systems can potentially lead to attention deficit and lymphadenitis, respectively. Additionally, diabetes can impact sexual health, resulting in decreased libido.

diagnoses.name: Substance Abuse
diagnoses.description: Substance abuse, including alcohol and drugs, can lead to a wide range of health issues, including dyspepsia, decreased libido, lymphadenitis (due to a weakened immune system), attention deficit, and even laryngitis (due to irritation or damage).

diagnoses.name: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
diagnoses.description: GERD can directly cause dyspepsia and laryngitis (from acid affecting the throat). While less directly, it can impact overall health and possibly contribute to symptoms like decreased libido, attention deficit, and even lymphadenitis through secondary mechanisms.

diagnoses: Nonsyndromic Hearing Loss and Deafness, DFNB1 (GJB2-Related)

diagnoses.name: Viral Infection
diagnoses.reasoning: Common viral infections can lead to laryngitis and general malaise which might explain the presyncope (near fainting) and difficulty focusing vision due to systemic effects.

diagnoses.name: Bacterial Infection
diagnoses.reasoning: Specific bacterial infections might cause periodontal disease and laryngitis, while systemic effects could account for the presyncope and vision issues.

diagnoses.name: Dehydration
diagnoses.reasoning: Dehydration can lead to presyncope and plethora while indirectly affecting the body’s immune response, potentially exacerbating or contributing to periodontal disease and laryngitis.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.reasoning: High blood sugar levels can cause plethora and contribute to periodontal disease. Vision problems are also a known complication of diabetes.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Diseases
diagnoses.reasoning: Certain autoimmune diseases can lead to symptoms like laryngitis (due to inflammation), periodontal disease, and vision problems.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.reasoning: Anemia can lead to presyncope due to reduced oxygen carrying capacity of blood and plethora if it's polycythemia as a compensatory mechanism.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.reasoning: Can lead to periodontal disease due to altered metabolism, potential voice changes or laryngitis due to myxedema, and may cause vision issues or presyncope.

diagnoses.name: Nutritional Deficiencies
diagnoses.reasoning: Vitamin and mineral deficiencies could lead to periodontal disease, affect vision, and compromise overall health, possibly leading to symptoms like presyncope.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: Can cause a wide range of symptoms including presyncope, difficulty focusing (cognitive impairment), but less directly related to the other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
diagnoses.reasoning: While primarily affecting the digestive system, GERD can occasionally lead to or worsen laryngitis due to acid reflux and may indirectly contribute to systemic symptoms like presyncope.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests
dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests
dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, but mostly the lungs and lymph glands. Characterized by the growth of tiny collections of inflammatory cells in different parts of the body.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: Cancer that begins in infection-fighting cells of the immune system, called lymphocytes. These cells are in the lymph nodes, spleen, thymus, bone marrow, and other parts of the body.

diagnoses.name: Mononucleosis (Mono)
diagnoses.description: An infectious illness usually caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, leading to fever, sore throat, swollen lymph glands, and fatigue.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) is a virus that attacks the body's immune system. If HIV is not treated, it can lead to AIDS (acquired immunodeficiency syndrome).

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. MS can result in a wide range of symptoms, including vision loss, pain, fatigue, and impaired coordination.

diagnoses.name: Myasthenia Gravis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune neuromuscular disease that causes weakness in the skeletal muscles, which are responsible for breathing and moving parts of the body, including the arms and legs.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.description: A disease caused by bacteria called Mycobacterium tuberculosis that most often affect the lungs but can also affect other parts of the body.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease in which the body's immune system mistakenly attacks its own tissues. It can affect the skin, joints, kidneys, brain, and other organs.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA)
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet. In RA, the body's immune system attacks its own tissue, including joints.

diagnoses.name: Syphilis
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection usually spread by sexual contact that starts as a painless sore. It can eventually affect the organs, including the brain and nerves.

diagnoses.name: Iron deficiency anemia
diagnoses.reasoning: Hypoferritinemia is a hallmark of iron deficiency, which can lead to anemia causing symptoms like irritability and easy bleeding due to decreased hemoglobin. Iron deficiency can also contribute to skin manifestations such as dyshydrotic eczema.

diagnoses.name: Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD)
diagnoses.reasoning: The presence of obsessive-compulsive behavior as a primary symptom suggests OCD, which can exacerbate or be associated with stress-related skin conditions like dyshydrotic eczema and systemic symptoms such as irritability.

diagnoses.name: Bleeding disorders (e.g., von Willebrand disease)
diagnoses.reasoning: Easy bleeding can indicate an underlying bleeding disorder. While not directly related to hypoferritinemia, iron deficiency can occur secondary to chronic blood loss, and stress or psychological factors in these conditions could potentially contribute to exacerbations of eczema or obsessive compulsive behaviors.

diagnoses.name: Atopic Dermatitis
diagnoses.reasoning: Though dyshydrotic eczema is a specific type of eczema, individuals with atopic dermatitis may also present with this condition, along with irritability due to the discomfort it causes. Atopic dermatitis could potentially correlate with immunological abnormalities that might affect iron metabolism, though indirectly.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Stress or Anxiety
diagnoses.reasoning: Chronic stress or high levels of anxiety can manifest physically as skin disorders, including dyshydrotic eczema, and psychologically as OCD-like behavior. These conditions could also lead to gastrointestinal changes affecting iron absorption, thereby contributing to hypoferritinemia.

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: Celiac disease can lead to malabsorption of nutrients including iron, resulting in hypoferritinemia. It can also cause skin manifestations, such as dermatitis herpetiformis, which could be confused with or exacerbate dyshydrotic eczema. OCD and irritability are associated with the psychological burden of chronic illnesses like celiac disease.

diagnoses.name: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD)
diagnoses.reasoning: Conditions such as Crohn’s disease or ulcerative colitis can cause malabsorption, leading to hypoferritinemia. They can also lead to extraintestinal manifestations such as skin issues. The chronic nature of IBD can affect mental health, potentially contributing to OCD symptoms and irritability.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid Disorders
diagnoses.reasoning: Both hypothyroidism and hyperthyroidism can lead to skin manifestations and may have a relationship with iron metabolism disorders. Additionally, thyroid dysfunction can contribute to mood swings or OCD-like symptoms due to hormonal imbalances.

diagnoses.name: Malabsorption Syndromes
diagnoses.reasoning: General malabsorption syndromes, beyond celiac disease, can result in hypoferritinemia. They may indirectly contribute to skin conditions due to nutrient deficiencies and can be associated with psychological stress or disorders due to chronic gastrointestinal symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Psychodermatologic Disorders
diagnoses.reasoning: This encompasses a range of conditions where psychological factors significantly impact skin health, leading to or exacerbating conditions like dyshydrotic eczema. OCD and irritability can both be causes and consequences in this complex interplay between mind and skin.

diagnoses: Inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, Ulcerative colitis)
Drug reactions (e.g., ACE inhibitors for angioedema)
Evans syndrome (autoimmune hemolytic anemia with thrombocytopenia)
Malignancy-associated hemolytic anemia and thrombocytopenia (e.g., lymphoma)
Drug Reactions with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Rheumatoid Arthritis with secondary Renal Involvement

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: Discoid rash and synovitis are common in SLE. Hemolytic anemia can also occur due to autoimmune destruction of red blood cells.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: Synovitis is a hallmark of rheumatoid arthritis, and while less common, anemia and rash can also be present as part of systemic involvement.

diagnoses.name: Ataxia-Telangiectasia
diagnoses.rationale: A rare condition characterized by telangiectasias, ataxia, and immunodeficiency. Hemolytic anemia can occur due to immune dysregulation.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia (Osler-Weber-Rendu Syndrome)
diagnoses.rationale: Characterized predominantly by telangiectasias, this condition can sometimes cause anemia, though usually through bleeding rather than hemolysis.

diagnoses.name: Scleroderma
diagnoses.rationale: Discoid rash and telangiectasias can be seen in scleroderma. Anemia can occur, and while synovitis is less common, joint symptoms can be part of the disease spectrum.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.rationale: Discoid lupus erythematosus might present with discoid rash, and systemic involvement might include symptoms such as synovitis and hemolytic anemia.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.rationale: This condition can present with features of several connective tissue diseases, including synovitis, rash, and potentially hemolytic anemia.

diagnoses.name: Evans Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: An autoimmune disorder where the body produces antibodies that attack its own red blood cells (hemolytic anemia) and platelets. Skin manifestations and joint symptoms can also occur.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.rationale: While primarily known for muscle symptoms, dermatomyositis can present with rash, and to a lesser extent, joint issues (which might resemble synovitis) and anemia due to chronic inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria
diagnoses.rationale: An acquired hematopoietic stem cell disorder that can cause hemolytic anemia. While the association with telangiectasias and discoid rash is less direct, it is a condition that could conceivably lead to a wide variety of systemic symptoms.

diagnoses: Hepatitis B or C associated nephropathies
Schizophrenia (due to potential misdiagnosis of psychosis)
Viral or Bacterial Infection leading to encephalitis or myelitis
Rheumatoid Arthritis with secondary Sjögren's syndrome
